title: How to Make Sprouts

methods.name: Growing Sprouts in a Mason Jar

steps.headline: Rinse your seeds in lukewarm water to clean them.
steps.description: Rinse until the water runs clear. Discard any split or otherwise obviously damaged seeds. Get rid of any rocks, dirt, or any foreign objects mixed in with your seeds. Alfalfa, broccoli, radish, mung bean, and lentils are easy to sprout. It's also possible to sprout soybeans, sunflowers, peas, onions, clover, kale, mustard, chickpeas, adzuki, buckwheat, quinoa, wheat, and wild rice.

steps.headline: Fill a 3 cups (710 mL) mason jar to around 1/4 full with seeds or beans.
steps.description: For small seeds, such as alfalfa, broccoli, barley, or mustard greens, use 1 to 2 tbsp (10-20 g). If you are using beans or lentils, use 1/4 to 1/2 cup (45-90 g). If you are using a jar of a different size, fill it no more than 1/4 full with seeds or beans.

steps.headline: Fill the jar with lukewarm, dechlorinated water.
steps.description: Filter or boil your water to dechlorinate it. Chlorine can kill your sprouts! You can also add 1 tsp (5 mL) of citric acid per quart (950 mL) of water. This is optional but can help reduce spoilage. You can find powdered citric acid at some grocery stores and health food stores.

steps.headline: Screw a sprouting lid onto the mouth of the jar.
steps.description: Sprouting lids are a hollow ring with a wire or plastic mesh insert. When you turn the jar over, the water will flow out but the mesh will retain the seeds. Sprouting lids come in various sizes. Select a size that your seeds can't slip through. As the seeds sprout, switch to a larger-mesh sprouting lid for better water and airflow. You can sprout seeds with just one sprouting lid, but having several sizes is helpful, especially if you're sprouting seeds of varying sizes. Alternatively, you can use cheesecloth over the mouth of the jar, held in place with a rubber band.

steps.headline: Soak your seeds for 6-36 hours in a warm location.
steps.description: Cover the jar with a lid to keep anything from falling into it. Room temperature, or around 70 °F (21 °C) is the ideal temperature for sprouting seeds. If you live somewhere cold, try keeping your seeds on top of your refrigerator or another appliance that gets warm.The bigger the seed, the longer it will need to sprout. Small seeds may only need 5 or 6 hours to sprout. Sunflower seeds typically take 1 to 2 days to sprout; clover, 4 days; broccoli, 3 days; alfalfa, 1 to 5 days; mung beans, 3 to 4 days. Seeds or beans with a hard coating, such as quinoa, chickpeas, or buckwheat may need to soak for as long as 36 hours.

steps.headline: Rinse the seeds 2-3 times a day if they don't sprout within 8 hours.
steps.description: Pour the water out of the sprouting jar. Fill the jar with lukewarm water, swirl the water and seeds together, then pour the rinse water out. Refill the jar with water to continue soaking the seeds. If you live in a hot, dry climate, rinse the seeds 3 times a day. Mung beans, soy beans, and chickpeas need to be rinsed more than other kinds of sprouts. Rinse them 3 or 4 times a day to prevent spoilage.

steps.headline: Drain the water once the seeds sprout 2 baby leaves.
steps.description: Once the seeds reach this point, the sprouts are ready to mature. Prop the jar at an angle, lid facing down, and let the water drain out completely. Leave the seeds in the jar after you drain the water.

steps.headline: Place the jar in a window for 2-3 hours until the sprouts turn green.
steps.description: Keep an eye on your sprouts! They are ready to eat once they turn green. Depending on how sunny it is where you live, sprouts in a sunny window can turn green within a couple of hours. The green color means the sprouts have matured and produced chlorophyll, which enhances their nutritional value.

steps.headline: Use high-quality sprouting seeds from a healthy grocer.
steps.description: Seeds specifically labeled for sprouting are usually tested to guarantee a good germination rate. You can find them at health food stores and online. Seeds not specifically labeled for sprouting are more susceptible to food-borne illnesses such as salmonella and e. coli.Alfalfa seeds are the most likely to cause foodborne illness since they can only be eaten raw. You can sprout almost any legume, seed, or nut, but avoid chia and flax seeds because they are hard to sprout, as well as kidney beans and quinoa, which can cause allergic reactions and nausea. You can also try your luck with organic seeds. Choose whole, untreated beans for the best results, as opposed to split beans. However, be aware of the chance that organic seeds are more likely to attract bacteria than seeds specifically labeled for sprouting. Many non-organic seeds sold for consumption are specially treated not to sprout.

steps.headline: Disinfect your containers before using them.
steps.description: Wash the mason jar or other container you use for sprouting with hot water and dish detergent. If possible, run your jars through the dishwasher.To sterilize a glass container, boil it in water for at least 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Store fresh, mature sprouts in a cheesecloth in the fridge below 40 °F (4 °C).
steps.description: Generally, sprouts eaten within a few days are safest and will have the best flavor. Fresh sprouts are best eaten within 3-4 days. Mung beans don't last as long as other sprouts and need to be eaten within 1-2 days. If your sprouts look or smell moldy, slimy, and rotten, don't eat them.Sprouts can grow bacteria if they are stored at temperatures above 40 °F (4 °C). Alternatively, you can keep fresh sprouts in a sealed container lined with a paper towel in the fridge for up to a week. Try to eat your sprouts while the root is still one thin thread; once sub-roots begin to appear, the sprouts are much less palatable.

steps.headline: Wash your sprouts before eating them.
steps.description: Place your sprouts in a colander. Run them cool water over them for around 1 minute, tossing the sprouts so that they are evenly rinsed. Lay them on a paper towel to drain.Wash your hands before you wash the sprouts so that you don't introduce more bacteria.

steps.headline: Avoid consuming raw sprouts if you are pregnant, elderly, a child, or immunocompromised.
steps.description: Raw sprouts are less safe than cooked sprouts, especially if you are at higher risk for disease. People who are pregnant, elderly, children, or have immune system diseases should cook sprouts thoroughly before eating them.Undercooked sprouts can be just as dangerous as raw sprouts.

steps.headline: Eat alfalfa sprouts raw.
steps.description: Alfalfa sprouts can't withstand heat and will turn to mush if you try to cook them. Try adding alfalfa sprouts to salads, sandwiches, or spring rolls.Add raw alfalfa sprouts as the last step to your recipe to give it more crunch and nutritional value.

steps.headline: Cook chickpea and adzuki sprouts for at least 15 minutes.
steps.description: Try roasting sprouted chickpeas or adzuki beans at 325 °F (163 °C) for 35-45 minutes for a crispy snack. Coat them in 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil, and your choice of spices. You can also add sprouted adzuki to your favorite soup recipe to add lots of extra protein.Try a combination of salt, garlic powder, onion powder, dill, and parsley for a savory snack, or cinnamon and sugar for a sweet snack. You can also use a dehydrator at 150 °F (66 °C) for 10 hours to completely dry out your sprouted beans.

steps.headline: Add mung bean sprouts to your favorite stir-fry recipe.
steps.description: Sauté mung beans in a very hot wok with ginger, garlic, salt, and pepper to taste. Serve them with rice, vegetables, tofu, or meat for a healthy and hearty stir-fry.Taste the sprouts as you are cooking them and adjust your seasoning as needed.

steps.headline: Add sprouts to chopped vegetables to make a sprout salad.
steps.description: Mix sprouted beans into finely chopped onions, tomatoes, and green chilies. Top the mixture with lemon juice and black pepper.You can also add in boiled potatoes or sweet potatoes for a hearty, filling salad. Add extra crunch with sunflower, sesame, or pumpkin seeds.

steps.headline: Top marinated tofu with fresh bean sprouts.
steps.description: Mix 1 sliced jalapeño with ⁄2 cup (120 mL) of soy sauce, 2 tbsp (12 g) of brown sugar, and 2 tsp (4 g) of ground ginger. Marinate firm tofu in this combination for around 30 minutes. Sauté your bean sprouts in 2 teaspoons (9.9 mL) of vegetable oil in a skillet over medium-high heat until they are charred. Serve the tofu and sprouts over rice.You can substitute this recipe for your favorite marinated tofu recipe.

Rinse until the water runs clear.
Discard any split or otherwise obviously damaged seeds.
Get rid of any rocks, dirt, or any foreign objects mixed in with your seeds.
Alfalfa, broccoli, radish, mung bean, and lentils are easy to sprout.
It's also possible to sprout soybeans, sunflowers, peas, onions, clover, kale, mustard, chickpeas, adzuki, buckwheat, quinoa, wheat, and wild rice.
Fill a 3 cups (710 mL) mason jar to around 1/4 full with seeds or beans.
For small seeds, such as alfalfa, broccoli, barley, or mustard greens, use 1 to 2 tbsp (10-20 g).
If you are using beans or lentils, use 1/4 to 1/2 cup (45-90 g).
If you are using a jar of a different size, fill it no more than 1/4 full with seeds or beans.
Fill the jar with lukewarm, dechlorinated water.
Filter or boil your water to dechlorinate it.
Chlorine can kill your sprouts!
You can also add 1 tsp (5 mL) of citric acid per quart (950 mL) of water.
This is optional but can help reduce spoilage.
You can find powdered citric acid at some grocery stores and health food stores.
Screw a sprouting lid onto the mouth of the jar.
Sprouting lids are a hollow ring with a wire or plastic mesh insert.
When you turn the jar over, the water will flow out but the mesh will retain the seeds.
Sprouting lids come in various sizes.
Select a size that your seeds can't slip through.
As the seeds sprout, switch to a larger-mesh sprouting lid for better water and airflow.
You can sprout seeds with just one sprouting lid, but having several sizes is helpful, especially if you're sprouting seeds of varying sizes.

Soak your seeds for 6-36 hours in a warm location.

If you live somewhere cold, try keeping your seeds on top of your refrigerator or another appliance that gets warm.The bigger the seed, the longer it will need to sprout.

Sunflower seeds typically take 1 to 2 days to sprout; clover, 4 days; broccoli, 3 days; alfalfa, 1 to 5 days; mung beans, 3 to 4 days.
Seeds or beans with a hard coating, such as quinoa, chickpeas, or buckwheat may need to soak for as long as 36 hours.

Mung beans, soy beans, and chickpeas need to be rinsed more than other kinds of sprouts.
Rinse them 3 or 4 times a day to prevent spoilage.
Drain the water once the seeds sprout 2 baby leaves.
Once the seeds reach this point, the sprouts are ready to mature.
